title: GNIS-LD- Serving and Visualizing the Geographic Names Information System As Linked Data

author: Blake Regalia, University of California, Santa Barbara

segmentation: Awesome, thanks for the introduction.

Hi, my name is Blake, so this resource it's called the GIS LD that is an acronym for the Geographic Names Information System, which is a gazetteer and what we did in this project is we converted it to linked data.
It's part of a bigger project.
I'll get to that.
Let me start just by defining some of these terms of using frequently so the USGS is the US Federal Scientific Agency for surveying and maintaining geographic records of the countries landscapes.
Do a lot of studies with geography, geology, biology, hydrology.
And they are the ones who are funding this project.
The Board on geographic names.
BGN is a federal body that is ensures that the usage of names for places in the US is consistent, appropriate, not going to cause clashes or confusion.
And so on for everything from rivers, to mountains, to streams.
And these have been around since, like the late 1800s.
Because obviously it started becoming a problem.
The naming of places in the US, which covers quite quite a large geographic extent.
The Geographic Names Information System, which is what this presentation is mostly about, abbreviated G NIS, is the authoritative public domain.
Gazetteer Gazetteer is a geographic register of place names.
And that's the product of the USGS and BGN their brainchild.
So a little bit about the GIS.

It was established because of inconsistencies and contradictions among surveyors and mapmakers and scientists in the 1800s, most notably after the Louisiana Purchase, where the US acquired a large amount of land.
It represents the names of places.
It also includes alternative names, their geographic location, of course.
Historical records about the place name, original map citations when the surveyor or the map maker produced the name on a map.
The cultural context of the name, and so on.
The data is made available as flat pipe delimited text records.
Essentially just a flat relational database tables.
And the GSGS has been around for so long that it appears in every major map data set that covers the US today.
Including.
Google Maps Open St Maps, Google, Apple, Bing mapsopenstreetmapjuniors.org Link, Geo data and so on.

So if you want to query the GIS in its current state, what you might do is open their web interface and enter a search term for any of these fields which includes feature name, the state, the County, what feature class it is.
There's about, I think, maybe a little more than 60 feature classes here, and these are top level feature classes that each one of those has sub feature types.
And then they also have the elevation and some other things that aren't shown in this search field, and this might be the reason.
So that you get back.
So we search for Lake Tahoe in California an you can get an idea of what types of fields.
That you'd get back, and this might be most notably used for like a geocoding service, where you're going to be trying to get the latitude in lanja tude.
Given a place name.
And of course you also get some other information such as the data was created and some of the other things I talked about.
This is the national map.
It represents the sum total of all geographic information surveyed by the USGS.
It contains many datasets and each one of those datasets is very rich.
So the point of the GIS is that it's basically acting as a hub that connects the names of places in the US with the geometric features, historical records acting as the entry points.
For these queries so.
In this data set we have or.

And you know, just to give.
An idea of how rich this data really is.
Everything that you see in this map here is sourced from USGS datasets.

That place has a name too.
So the project that we received funding for is essentially to publish all this national map datasets as linked data and that starts with the GIS.
So just a little bit more background about this project.
The USGS funded all USGS funded projects are required.
That requires that all deliverables, including the tools used the software developed and the data produced are open source and based on open standards.

Let's see so little recap.

Our objective is to convert the GIS to link data in this resource and produce a core vocabulary and ontology, as well as aligning all the data that we produce from that with existing repository such as geonames.org, Dbpedia, Getty, ADL and so on.
As well as to supply a Geo enabled user interface for dereferencing and browsing all these features.
So at this point you might be wondering well, how exactly does this relate to link Geo data repository's such as Jew names.org, an linked Geo data.
So first of all, like I said before, every single data set geographic data set you've ever heard about or seen that covers the US at one point imported the GIS data set.
Either directly or indirectly.
And however, they do not all reflect the current version of the GIS.
And So what we're providing here is an authoritative, comprehensive triple ified version of the most up-to-date data set for the US.
The GIS publishes updates every two months.
Furthermoregeonames.org specifically is not currently five star link data.
It has no sparkle endpoint linked Geo data only supports a subset of the SQL MSPE ATIAL specification.
Where is GNSLD offers full Geo sparkle support.
So I'm just going to jump into the results and then I'm going to kind of work backwards from there a little bit.
So here we have one feature.
This is Lake Tahoe.
The GIS feature for Lake Tahoe, and this is the web interface that we developed specifically for these datasets that we're going to be publishing.

In this example.

We've pulled, we found this feature by actually finding the DB Pedia article for Lake Tahoe because we produce same as links to the pedia and then traverse it to the feature so that just gives you an idea of maybe one way that you would find a feature like this rather than searching for the full text string.
Maybe you start with the Pedia article and then you work your way towards the GIS feature.
Then of course we have, you know the data model gives us things like the place tape, place type, hierarchy, the label, alternative names, state, County, elevation, geometry and so forth.
And just to demonstrate the real value of this GIS data set from this interface.

Which represents the name of Lake Tahoe we can see at the bottom that it is linked to AN HD feature in the incoming triple section, which basically means that there are some NHD feature that is referring to the GIS data set.
With this feature.
So here we have the geometry for that HD feature, which shows us the waterbody of Lake Tahoe, which is a Polygon and anyone familiar with.
Using Geo Link data might notice that we're not using Geo SPARQL here.
We're using our own a Geo ontology and to give more explanation about the.
This is really the crux of one of the reasons that we wanted to publish this resource.
What we do instead of using well known text strings is that we are storing all the geometry's.
In binary and binary formats, and then only representing that geometry within YRI.

We still support all geospatial functions.
